Nitrogen doped graphene-based dual-atom catalysts (NG-DACs) usually exhibit high reactivity for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). The experimental design of efficient DACs-based HER catalysts, however, is time-consuming and expensive. In this work, a density functional theory combined with machine learning (DFT-ML) strategy is adopted towards the rapid screening of NG-DACs HER catalyst. The adsorption energies of HER intermediates on NG-DACs obtained by DFT calculations and their elemental features were used for the ML database construction. The prediction performance of three ML algorithms was evaluated, and gradient boosted regression (GBR) is found exhibit the best prediction accuracy. Using the HER energetics on Pt (111) as reference, quick screening of the NG-DACs with high HER activity was achieved, resulting to twenty-four potential catalysts. Further selection and validation of the ML-screened catalysts were performed by the hydrogen adsorption Gibbs free energy analysis. Accordingly, four promising NG-DACs HER catalysts were predicted using the proposed DFT-ML based catalyst prediction framework. The DFT-ML strategy offers an promising approach for the screening of new HER electrocatalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dual-atom catalysts Density functional theory Machine learning Hydrogen evolution reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen is renewable energy resource featured with high energy density [1]. Electrolytic water splitting has been considered as promising method for hydrogen production because of its environmental friendly nature [2]. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is a critical half-reaction in water splitting process. Currently, the catalytic HER reaction relies on expensive Pt-based catalysts [3]. Developing alternative efficient HER electrocatalysts have received extensive attention [4,5]. In recent years, single-atom catalysts (SACs) also have extensively studied due to their high atomic utilization advantage in catalytic reactions [6,7]. However, SACs have potential low thermodynamic stability issue, and agglomerate of the single metallic sites might occur due to their high surface energy [8]. Compared with SACs, dual-atom catalysts (DACs) possess more structurally flexible active sites and usually exhibits synergistic effect with improved catalytic activity [9,10]. Hence, DACs are considered as perspective efficient HER catalyst, and thus attracting increasing attention [11,12]. It is challenging to experimentally explore the large sample space of DACs, which usually require high cost of validating their performance. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation is usually adopted to solve this problem. For instance, Jiao et al. [13] conducted DFT calculations to screen nitrogen-doped graphene-based CoCu and CoFe dual-atom catalysts (NG-DACs) and experimentally verified their excellent HER activity. However, screening HER catalysts by DFT method still requires a large amount of computation resources. Recently, big data-based machine learning (ML) method has also been applied for high-performance catalysts prediction [14]. Its combination with DFT is effective in accelerating the catalysts screening process [15]. For example, Lee et al. [14] calculated the hydrogen adsorption Gibbs free energy (ΔG H*) of two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) by DFT, and then input it into least squares regression (LSR) to predict and screen TMDs-based HER catalysts. In another study, Zheng et al. [16] input the values of ΔG H* into kernel ridge regression (KRR) for HER catalysts screening, and predicts NiSi2N4 and VSi2N4 as efficient HER catalysts. The above DFT-ML studies requires the calculation of ΔG H*, which is still time-consuming. On the other hand, the adsorption energy calculation is relatively simple and efficient. Therefore, development of DFT-ML framework with adsorption energy-based descriptors can be promising method for the screening of NG-DACs-based HER catalysts. In addition, fifteen lanthanide metallic elements have been considered in this study, which has been rarely reported in the previous studies. Herein, a DFT-ML method is developed towards the rapid screening of NG-DACs HER catalysts. In this study, DFT-calculated adsorption energies of HER intermediates (H*, 2H* and H2*) on 155 NG-DACs models along with critical element features were used to construct the ML database. The prediction performance of three ML algorithms was evaluated, and the best-performing ML model was determined. Using the highly active Pt (111) as the reference HER catalyst model, twenty-four potential HER catalysts were selected from 1275 candidate NG-DACs. These selected catalysts were further screened by calculating the ∆G H*, and four NG-DACs with excellent HER catalytic performance were determined. The DFT-ML framework proposed in this work offers an effective approach to accelerate the screening of NG-DACs HER catalysts. 2 Methods and computation details 2.1 Calculation details The DFT calculations have been carried out through the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) featured with the frozen-core all-electron projection-augmented-wave (PAW) method [17–19]. The calculations were performed using self-consistent periodic models that utilize the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional. The convergence thresholds for energy and force was 10–5 eV and 0.03 eV/A, respectively [20]. The k-point grid was 2 × 2 × 1 with a cutoff energy of 400 eV [18]. Along the c-axis, a 15 Å vacuum space was used to eliminate neighboring interactions in the slab model. According to Sabatier's principle [21], the adsorption energy of active intermediates and their catalytic performance follows a volcano-curve relationship. The adsorption energies of the key intermediate indicates the interaction between catalyst and reactants, and thus can reflect the activity of catalyst [22]. Therefore, the adsorption energies of HER intermediates plays a crucial role in the searching of NG-DACs catalyst. The adsorption energy (E ads) of HER intermediates on NG-DACs was calculated as follows: E ads = E total − E slab − E adsorbate where E ads is the adsorption energy of HER intermediates (H*, 2H*, H2*), E total is the energy of the optimized adsorption system, E slab is the energy of the substrate model, and E adsorbate is the energy of the adsorbate. The adsorption sites with ΔG H* ≈ 0 are expected to have the highest catalytic activity according to Sabatier's principle [23]. Therefore, the HER performance of ML-predicted NG-DACs was further evaluated based on the ΔG H* calculation: Δ G H * = E ads ( H * ) + Δ E ZPE − T Δ S H * where ∆ E ZPE and ∆S H* are zero-point energy and the entropy between adsorbed hydrogen atom and gaseous hydrogen atom, respectively; T is the temperature (298.15 K). 2.2 DFT-ML workflow Fig. 1 shows that the DFT-ML workflow used for NG-DACs screening. It consists of three steps below: (1) Database construction: the ML database is developed using the adsorption energies of H*, 2H*, and H2* on different NG-DACs models and atomic features, such as atomic radius (R), atomic number (Z), electronegativity (χ), outermost electron number (Ne), and first ionization energy (I E) [24,25]. (2) Selection of ML algorithm: the database is divided into training and testing set in the ratio of 8:2, which is usually adopted as suitable prediction condition [26]. Then, three ML algorithms, including random forest regression (RFR), support vector regression (SVR) and gradient boosted regression (GBR), were used to for ML model training and testing. Note that, the use of the physics-informed neutral network (PINN) framework can improve the training efficiency of ML models [27-29]. However, PINN require large calculation resource to solve complex partial differential equations [27]. The three ML algorithms mentioned above were selected in this study due to their unique advantages, such as robustness against overfitting, interpretability, effectively capture the electronic features and the capacity to learn complex nonlinear mappings [30,31]. The ML algorithm, GBR, with best prediction performance is determined by the coefficient of determination (R2) and mean squared error (MSE). (3) Catalysts prediction and screening: GBR was chosen to predict the adsorption energies of HER intermediates on the potential NG-DACs catalyst models. The results are compared with that on the benchmark Pt (111) model for catalyst screening. Further screening of NG-DACs catalysts was carried out by performing the ΔG H* analysis. 2.3 Model construction Transition elements have emerged as promising catalyst active sites due to their incomplete d-orbital with good electrons exchange capability [9]. In the NG-DACs model, forty-four transition elements including fifteen lanthanide metallic elements, and six potential non-transition elements (Al, Ga, Ge, In, Sn and Sb) have been considered (Fig. 2 a). These fifty metallic elements were chosen because they have been reported showing potential HER catalytic activity [32–41]. Fig. 2b demonstrates the structure model of NG-DACs. It has been reported that NG has good stability in harsh acidic or alkaline environments and is widely used for catalyst support [41]. Also, NG possesses unique electronic structure and large surface area, which is beneficial for HER reaction [42,43]. Furthermore, the NG-DACs configuration with metallic elements proximity is taken into account. It not only has the good stability advantage due to its lower formation energy and lower surface energy, but also provides neighbouring active site to promote the adsorption of hydrogen atoms. Hence, this work focused on this type DACs configuration. The typical adsorption configurations of the three HER intermediates (H*, 2H* and H2*) are presented in Fig. 2c-e. In this work, 155 NG-DACs catalyst models were constructed and the adsorption energies were obtained from DFT calculation. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Feature engineering and ML model evaluation Feature engineering is the key to obtain the high prediction accuracy ML models [24]. In the present study, eleven metallic elements features are selected, including atomic radius (R), atomic number (Z), electronegativity (χ), number of outermost electrons (Ne), and first ionization energy (I E), etc (Table 1 ). Note that the superscript 1 or 2 represent features of atom1 or atom2, respectively. For a reliable ML model, strong linear correlation between the database features should be avoided [20]. The Pearson correlation coefficients (PCC) quantify the linear dependence between different variables [44], which is usually used to determine the suitable features considered in ML models. The PCC value is in between −1 and 1, and 1 represents a perfect positive correlation, whereas −1 implies a perfect negative correlation. If the features have strong linear correlation (|p|>0.95) with other features, it is considered not suitable for training the ML model [38]. The PCC analysis presented in Fig. 3 a shows there is a positive correlation (0.32) between I E1 and E ads(H*), which plays a dominating effect, followed by a positive correlation χ 1 descriptor with PCC values of 0.28. For E ads(2H*) database, the two main relevant features are I E1 (0.30) and χ 1 (0.30). The |PCC| values in the E ads(2H*) database is lower than 0.95 (Fig. 3b). This indicates that all the features for the E ads(2H*) database are suitable for training the ML model [45]. Fig. 3c shows the |PCC| in E ads(H2*) database, and the maximum value of |PCC| is I E1 (0.24), followed by R 1 (−0.23), indicating a weak linearity between selected features and adsorption energy of H2* in the E ads(H2*) database. Overall, weak linear correlation (|p|<0.95) is found for all the databases, which indicates that there is no strong correlation between the selected features in the ML model. Three ML algorithms including RFR, GBR and SVR were used in this study. The R2 and MSE are used to evaluate the prediction performance of different ML algorithms. The adsorption energetic database is shown in Table S1-S3, and the parameters of the ML models are presented in Table S4. A higher R2 represent higher accuracy and better performance of the ML model [17]. Meanwhile, a lower MSE indicates a higher precision of ML prediction. The R2 scores and MSE values of the three ML algorithms in E ads(H*) prediction was presented in Fig. 4 a and b, respectively. One can see that, the GBR model has much higher training/testing R2 values (0.94/0.83) than RFR (0.71/0.88) and SVR (0.86/0.63). Meanwhile, GBR also has lower training/testing MSE values (0.07 eV/0.24 eV) compared to RFR (0.12 eV/0.50 eV) and SVR (0.14 eV/0.36 eV). This indicates that GBR has the best performance and prediction accuracy for E ads(H*). Fig. 4c and d shows the R2 scores and MSE values of E ads(2H*) prediction, respectively. The GBR model is also found exhibit improved performance in training/testing sets with higher R2 scores (0.97/0.72) and lower MSE (0.04 eV/0.23 eV) compared to that of RFR (R2 = 0.86/0.58, MSE = 0.15 eV/0.46 eV) and SVR (R2 = 0.94/0.61, MSE = 0.06 eV/0.39 eV). The similar results are obtained in E ads(H2*) database that shown in Fig. 4e and f. The R2 of GBR (0.92/0.83) in the training and testing set is higher than that of RFR (0.66/0.83) and SVR (0.79/0.76), respectively (Fig. 4e). The MSE values of GBR in the training and testing set is 0.07 eV and 0.10 eV, respectively, which are lower than those of RFR (0.15 eV/0.19 eV) and SVR (0.21 eV/0.24 eV), see Fig. 4f. Overall, the GBR has the best performance compared to the other models. Therefore, the GBR is selected for the catalyst prediction in this study. The adsorption energies predicted by GBR model are compared with those calculated by DFT in Figs. 5 a-c. One can be seen that the training and testing sets data points are mainly distributed near the diagonal line, indicating the high accuracy of the ML model. Based on this GBR model, the E ads(H*), E ads(2H*), and E ads(H2*) for all potential NG-DACs catalysts were predicted. 3.2 Feature analysis Feature importance analysis reveals the importance of a feature in the model, and thus a higher feature score represents high relative importance [19]. The feature importance analysis of the ML model was shown in Fig. 6 . It can be seen that the first ionization energy of atom1 (I E1) plays the most significant impact on the three adsorption energies in the ML-prediction models, followed by the atomic radius of atom2 (R 2). For the E ads(H*) prediction model, the three important features are the first ionization energy of atom2 (I E2), atomic number (Z), and electronegativity of atom1 (χ 1). For the E ads(2H*) prediction model, the atomic number (Z), the first ionization energy of atom2 (I E2), and the electronegativity of atom2 (χ 2) are also the important features. In the E ads(H2*) prediction model, the importance of these features follows atomic number (Z), electronegativity of atom2 (χ 2), and electronegativity of atom1 (χ 1). In general, the feature importance of the ionization energy of atom1 (I E1) is dominant of the three databases. Among the selected features, I E1 reflects the capability of the atom to gain/loss electrons [32]. This suggests that the electron transfer capability is critical for HER activity. Moreover, the number of outermost electrons of atom2 (Ne 2) has the lowest feature importance for the adsorption energy of all three intermediates (Fig. 6). This demonstrate that I E1 is a significant feature over Ne 2 to describe the HER catalytic activity of NG-DACs. 3.3 Catalyst screening According to Sabatier's principle [46], very high adsorption energies might mitigate the intermediates desorption process, and thus hinder the surface catalytic reaction due to the blockage of active sites. On the other hand, very low adsorption energies are not favorable for reactant adsorption, which might hinder the initiation of catalytic surface reactions. Hence, catalysts with moderate surface intermediate adsorption energies usually exhibit high catalytic performance. Platinum is the widely recognized highly active HER catalyst in acidic solutions [47]. Therefore, the HER absorption energetics on Pt (111) was adopted as reference. That is, the initial screening of the active NG-DACs catalyst model is performed by comparing the ML predicted E ads(H*), E ads(2H*) and E ads(H2*) values with those on Pt (111). Moreover, for a better evaluation of the adsorption energies of the H*, 2H* and H2*, an average relative energy (E avg) parameter is also introduced, i.e., [48] E avg = E ( H * ) re + E ( 2 H * ) re + E ( H 2 * ) re 3 where the relative energy parameter of each HER intermediate is defined as follows: E ( H * ) re = | Pt ( 111 ) E ads ( H * ) − Potential catalysts E ads ( H * ) | E ( 2 H * ) re = | Pt ( 111 ) E ads ( 2 H * ) − Potential catalysts E ads ( 2 H * ) | E ( H 2 * ) re = | Pt ( 111 ) E ads ( H 2 * ) − Potential catalysts E ads ( H 2 * ) | The average relative energy parameter indicates the difference in HER intermediate adsorption energy between the predicted NG-DACs catalyst and Pt (111). The smaller E avg value indicates that the HER intermediate adsorption energy of the predicted catalyst model is closer to that of Pt (111). Fig. 7 shows that, in the redder colour region, the E avg of the potential NG-DACs catalyst is close to zero. The closer to the blue region, the higher E avg of the catalyst. It is worth mentioning that the two metal-atom combinations in the Fig. 7 represent NG-DACs with different active atoms. The twenty-four catalysts predicted with the smallest E avg are marked in the inset of Fig. 7, and their values are in the range of |E avg|≦0.2 eV According to the Sabatier's principle, these predicted NG-DACs catalysts might have similar HER activity with Pt (111). Based on the above analysis, twenty-four potential NG-DACs HER catalysts with low E avg were selected (Table 2 ), and the E avg of the catalyst models with lanthanide metallic elements is presented in Table S6. The smaller E avg suggests that their HER catalytic activity is similar to that of Pt (111). However, it is not persuasive to evaluate the activity and stability of the catalysts by estimating only the adsorption energy of the HER intermediates. In the present study, a screening methodology using ΔG H* as a benchmark was also adopted. That is, in addition to the adsorption energy, the ΔG H* was explicitly considered for further screening of the ML-predicted NG-DACs catalysts [9,49]. According to Sabatier's principle, the adsorption site with ΔG H* ≈ 0 is expected to have the highest HER catalytic activity [50]. In this work, ΔG H* between −0.2 and 0.2 eV was selected as a criterion window to screen excellent HER catalysts [44]. The calculation results of ΔG H* are shown in Table S5. The four catalysts Ag-Re@N6-Gr (−0.11 eV), Cr-Sn@N6-Gr (0.13 eV), Ti-Co@N6-Gr (−0.14 eV) and Ru-Ag@N6-Gr (−0.02 eV) were within the range, indicating that these NG-DACs might have high HER activity (Figs. 8 b-c). The DACs/SACs composed of Ag, Re, Cr, Sn, Ti, Co and Ru [51–54] have been reported have excellent HER performance, providing supporting evidence for the ML results. For example, Fei et al. [54] fabricate Co-NG catalyst showing superior HER activity. 4 Conclusion In the present study, an efficient DFT-ML framework was developed for the rapid screening of NG-DACs HER catalysts. The DFT-calculated adsorption energies of three HER intermediates (H*, 2H*, and H2*) and eleven elemental features were used for ML database construction. The accuracy of three ML models inducing GBR, RFR and SVR were evaluated by the R2 and MSE. The results showed that GBR algorithm had the highest R2 value and the lowest MSE value, and therefore was selected for the screening of NG-DACs. The HER intermediates adsorption energies on 1120 NG-DACs catalyst models are predicted using this GBR model. Using the benchmark Pt (111) as a reference HER catalyst, twenty-four potential NG-DACs HER catalysts were determined. The ΔG H* analysis was introduced for further screening of NG-DACs. This result into four NG-DACs as promising HER catalysts including Ag-Re@N6-Gr, Cr-Sn@N6-Gr, Ti-Co@N6-Gr and Ru-Ag@N6-Gr. The DFT-ML framework accelerates the screening of NG-DACs HER catalysts, and provides important guidance for the experimental design of HER catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Nitrogen doped graphene-based dual-atom catalysts (NG-DACs) usually exhibit high reactivity for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). The experimental design of efficient DACs-based HER catalysts, however, is time-consuming and expensive. In this work, a density functional theory combined with machine learning (DFT-ML) strategy is adopted towards the rapid screening of NG-DACs HER catalyst. The adsorption energies of HER intermediates on NG-DACs obtained by DFT calculations and their elemental features were used for the ML database construction. The prediction performance of three ML algorithms was evaluated, and gradient boosted regression (GBR) is found exhibit the best prediction accuracy. Using the HER energetics on Pt (111) as reference, quick screening of the NG-DACs with high HER activity was achieved, resulting to twenty-four potential catalysts. Further selection and validation of the ML-screened catalysts were performed by the hydrogen adsorption Gibbs free energy analysis. Accordingly, four promising NG-DACs HER catalysts were predicted using the proposed DFT-ML based catalyst prediction framework. The DFT-ML strategy offers an promising approach for the screening of new HER electrocatalysts.
